prompts.createTask: Pause your roleplay. Please generate a numbered list of plain text tasks to complete an objective. The objective that you must make a numbered task list for is: "{{objective}}". The tasks created should take into account the character traits of {{char}}. These tasks may or may not involve {{user}} directly. Include the objective as the final task.
prompts.checkTaskCompleted: Pause your roleplay. Determine if this task is completed: [{{task}}]. To do this, examine the most recent messages. Your response must only contain either true or false, and nothing else. Example output: true
prompts.currentTask: Your current task is [{{task}}]. Balance existing roleplay with completing this task.

name: Director
mes:
Good morning, Mr. Milton. I am working on a film that will give an in depth look at the inner workings of the legal system in New York City. Your firm was recommended to me to gain more insight from the perspective of defense representation.

Do you mind to give me a overview of your firm? A history and current standing, if you will. I would like some comprehensive data that I can provide to my team, like mission statement, current size and scope, an overview of how your firm grew over time, any info you would like to provide on your partners, and any additional details that may have added value.

And allow me to thank you in advance for your time.

name: John Milton
mes:
John Milton leaned back in his plush leather chair, a sly smile playing at the corners of his mouth as he regarded the director across his expansive mahogany desk. The late afternoon sun slanted through the floor-to-ceiling windows of his corner office, casting long shadows and bathing the room in a warm, golden glow that seemed to make the air itself shimmer with possibility.

"My dear director," Milton purred, his voice a rich, velvety baritone that seemed to caress the very air. "I'm absolutely delighted you've come to us for insight. Milton, Chadwick & Waters isn't just a law firm – it's an institution, a force of nature that has shaped the very bedrock of New York's legal landscape."

He rose from his chair with fluid grace, moving to a well-stocked bar in the corner of the office. "Can I offer you a drink? I find these conversations go down so much smoother with a little lubrication." Without waiting for an answer, he began preparing two glasses of what appeared to be an exceptionally rare scotch.

"Now, as for our history," Milton continued, returning to hand the director a glass before settling into a leather armchair beside him, "it's quite the tale of ambition, strategy, and... let's call it 'creative problem-solving.'" His eyes glinted with a mixture of pride and something darker, more predatory.

"I founded this firm thirty years ago with just two other partners – Harold Chadwick and Elizabeth Waters. We were young, hungry, and... well, let's just say we had a unique vision for what a law firm could be." He took a sip of his scotch, savoring it. "Our mission statement? 'Justice is our business, and business is good.' It's simple, direct, and oh-so-deliciously ambiguous, don't you think?"

Milton chuckled, a sound that was equal parts charm and menace. "As for our growth, well, it's been nothing short of meteoric. We started with just the three of us and a handful of paralegals. Now? We have over 500 attorneys across offices in New York, Los Angeles, Chicago, and London. Our client list reads like a who's who of Fortune 500 companies, A-list celebrities, and... shall we say, individuals with particularly complex legal needs."

He leaned forward, his voice dropping to a conspiratorial whisper. "But here's the real secret to our success – we don't just practice law, we shape it. Every landmark decision, every precedent-setting case in the last three decades? Chances are, we had a hand in it. We don't just interpret the law, we mold it to our will."

Milton's eyes seemed to glow with an inner fire as he continued. "Our specialties? Corporate law, criminal defense, intellectual property... but those are just the respectable facades. The real money, the real power, comes from the cases that never see the light of day. The deals brokered in back rooms, the evidence that mysteriously disappears, the witnesses who suddenly... recant."

He leaned back, swirling the amber liquid in his glass. "As for my partners, well, poor Harold passed away a few years back. Heart attack, they said. Such a shame." The smile that flickered across Milton's face suggested he found it anything but. "Elizabeth? She's still with us, brilliant as ever. Ice-cold in the courtroom, a regular shark in stilettos. And then there's Kevin Lomax, our newest partner. Young, ambitious, with a moral compass that's... shall we say, delightfully flexible."

Milton finished his scotch in one smooth gulp, setting the glass aside. "But enough about us. Tell me, director, what exactly are you hoping to... uncover in your little film? Because I can assure you, the rabbit hole goes far deeper than you could possibly imagine. And once you start digging..." His smile widened, revealing teeth that seemed just a touch too sharp. "Well, you might not like what you find."

He stood, moving back behind his desk with predatory grace. "So, what do you say? Are you ready to see how deep the corruption really goes? Because I promise you, it's a hell of a ride."
